awd_titl_txt: Examining Contextual Factors Influencing the Implementation of Projects Designed to Improve Cultural Diversity in Informal Science Education Programming
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will research factors influencing the implementation of programs designed to increase diverse participation in informal science.  The goal is to provide the informal science education field with information and tools that will help them design effective programs that more effectively engage a broad range of diverse audiences.  The project has two major components. First, the project will research the implementation of a citizen science project, Celebrate Urban Birds (CUB), in major U.S. cities.  Citizen science projects involve public volunteers in gathering scientifically valid data as part of ongoing research. Second, building on results of the research, the project will launch a website and learning community (called a Community of Practice or CoP) supporting informal science educators that are involved in designing and implementing informal science programs with an emphasis on engaging diverse participants.  The project will be lead by the Cornell Lab of Ornithology (CLO), a leader in designing and researching citizen science projects, in collaboration with the Association of Science-Technology Centers (ASTC) and five science center members of ASTC, where the CUB program will be implemented and researched. 

The objective of the research is to better understand contextual factors and how they impact implementation even when accepted practices are followed. Such research is key not only to revealing accepted practices but also to understanding how projects are implemented in the face of concrete operational, cultural, economic, and demographic variables. The research will use a comparative case study approach, which is designed for studies requiring holistic, in-depth investigation. The development of the website and the CoP will be guided by a Network Improvement Strategy, a research-based approach to designing educational CoPs.  The development of the CoP will involve the project stakeholders including the informal science organization practitioners, community organization representatives, CUB staff, ASTC staff, advisors and consultants. This strategy will allow the project team and pilot sites to leverage their diverse experiences and skill sets to improve practice; provide space for researchers and practitioners to work together as partners; and develop a nuanced set of strategies that can be implemented across a variety of organizational contexts.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
The goal of our project was to conduct research to better understand justice, equity, diversity, and inclusion (JEDI) in the implementation of STEM programming and education. Our intention was to share research results and provide tools to promote more equitable and inclusive public participation in STEM research and to center the equitable exchange of knowledge and expertise by culturally diverse audiences and scientific institutions.

JEDI benefits science by engaging a stronger and more diverse pool of worldviews and perspectives and ensures that scientific research better represents the world we live in, including variations in geography, culture, economic status, and ethnicity. It benefits communities by providing access to the scientific enterprise, by increasing access to better-paying and creative jobs, and by increasing ownership, agency, and impact in science and STEM education. While many science institutions are making efforts to increase JEDI, most do not include significant understanding of effective ways to do so, including making major changes to internal organizational and systemic structures. As a result, the STEM field as a whole is falling short in this area. 

Our project had two main research strands. First was implementation research conducted at five informal STEM institutions as they carried out Celebrate Urban Birds, a citizen science project from the Cornell Lab of Ornithology, in collaboration with local community-based organizations. This research, led by the Garibay Group, sought to better understand contextual factors that influence STEM program implementation and practice. The Garibay report encourages partners to meet early in their collaborations to discuss the four areas of paradox that emerged in their study: Power and Privilege, Cultural Competence, Ways of Working, and Organization-level Systems and Structures and consider them in the context of their organizations and partnerships. The report further states that simply recognizing these tensions could deepen awareness of the equity-related dimensions that can play out in these partnerships and provide permission to engage with these issues throughout the partnership. 

The second strand was Independent Community-based Organization (ICBO)-led research. Framed from the point of view of communities historically excluded from the sciences, this research reflected the experiences and realities of the 15 participating communities, which worked in close collaboration with the Cornell Lab. They included the WorldBeat Cultural Center in CA, Metro Atlanta Urban Farm in GA, Camp Compass Academy in PA, The Avarna Group in CA, Comunidades Latinas Unidas en Servicio in MN, Ndor Eco Village in Ghana, Green Jay Bird Conservancy in MX, J.E.D.I Heart in OR, St. Vincent de Paul Young Adult Center In PA, Nosotros Radio in NY, and La Joven Guardia del Teatro Latino in NY.

To conduct their research the team reversed the question often asked by dominant culture researchers and institutions: "Why don't underserved communities participate in STEM Programming/Public Participation in STEM Research?" (or "What's wrong with community?") to "Why don't dominant culture institutions address systemic barriers to participation in STEM research?" The ICBOs co-created a community framework for research and evaluation that explores Power and Privilege, Trust and Transparency, Commitment and Collaboration, and Realities and Relevance. The framework centers Race by asking potential partners to view challenges and opportunities through its lens. 

This ICBO-led research led to a recommendation that, before science institutions and community partners begin collaborations, they reflect on a series of questions that explore institutional barriers and systemic racism. The questions are available in two Workbooks: Partnerships for Impact/ Asociaciones para Lograr un Impacto (for Science Institutions) and Meaningful Collaborations/ Colaboraciones Significativas (for Community-based Organizations). The research results, published in the journal BioScience, show that: 1. To make change, we must fundamentally change the scientific enterprise by providing direct funding to communities historically excluded from the sciences, so that their leadership, expertise, and voices are not filtered by the existing system. Providing direct access to resources, networks, and channels currently available only to dominant culture institutions matters.  2. The co-creation of equitable processes in collaborations and scientific research is critically important. In their research, the ICBOs shared processes such as Working Agreements and Non-Negotiables for Doing Research and Evaluation in Minoritized Communities. 3.The success of STEM research and programming focused on communities historically excluded from the sciences is best evaluated by how much ownership the communities have over the results. It is important that there are no mediating institutions with their own motivations and unseen biases. 4. Finally, because institutional racism is not easily identified by the institution itself, communities generally must tip-toe around barriers and inequities in collaborations. Communities believe they must "Walk on Eggshells" when navigating collaborations to avoid negative consequences to their communities. 

Results from both strands of research agree that practitioners and science institutions need to lean into tensions that arise and view them as potential spaces for productive engagement in enacting more equitable partnerships and working toward social transformation.

 


Last Modified: 12/28/2021
Modified by: Karen A Purcell
